Award.AwardTitle: MSM Collaborative Research: Agricultural expansion in the Brazilian Amazon and its influence on the water, energy, and climate cycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Amazon has suffered extensive deforestation in recent years as a result of a large increase in global demand for beef and soy. Deforestation changes groundwater and stream flow in both small and large river basins and, in the future, may cause a hotter and drier climate in the Amazon. How much the water resources of the Amazon have already changed, as well as how much they may change in the future is not known. This project addresses the consequences of agricultural expansion on the water resources of the Amazon by combining data collection and computer models. Stream flow and climate data will be gathered in 23 watersheds in evergreen forest, savanna, pasture, and soy environments to understand the effects of deforestation on the local water and energy balance. The data will be used with existing computer models to provide a large-scale analysis of the effects of past and future deforestation on the energy and water cycles of the Amazon.

Farmers, policymakers, educators, students, and the public will have opportunities to learn about the effects of land use change as a result of this project. Data generated and lessons learned will be used to develop stream health measures that can be applied on an existing network of properties covering more than 1.8 million hectares (4.5 million acres), in Brazil. The project will provide direct financial and technical support to at least four PhD students in the US and Brazil, as well as master's and undergraduate students from the State University of Mato Grosso at Nova Xavantina. The work will also support and expand an influential teacher educational program in Mato Grosso, Brazil, strengthening science education ties between middle schools in Mato Grosso, Brazil, and Falmouth, MA. It will also send two science journalists each year to Brazil for hands-on training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MSM Collaborative Research: Agricultural Expansion in the Brazilian Amazon and its Influence on the Water, Energy, and Climate Cycles

 M.T. Coe, C. Neill, M.H. Costa, and P Moutinho

 Intellectual Merit

 Forests in the Amazon Basin and Brazilian savannas (cerrados) have been replaced by pastures and, increasingly in the last two decades, by soybean croplands. Because this land use transition replaces forest and woody savanna vegetation with lower-stature croplands, it has the potential to cause large changes to the water and energy cycles of the Amazon across all spatial scales. At small scales, land conversion causes a decrease in evapotranspiration and an increase in streamwater runoff, due to the lower water demands of the plants replacing native vegetation. At larger scales, however, the decreased return of water vapor to the atmosphere has the potential to reduce regional rainfall, therefore reducing streamwater runoff and further decreasing evapotranspiration.

In this project, runoff was monitored continuously in twenty-one gauged watersheds representing forest, cerrado, pasture and soybean land uses in the Xingu Basin, a region of southeastern Amazonia where agricultural expansion has been most intense. Together with climate data, these field measurements were used to quantify the water balance under each land cover and validate surface energy balance models. A combination of field observations, satellite-derived landscape metrics (e.g. riparian forest buffers, land cover, small impoundments), and statistical modeling was used to quantify the cumulative impacts of recent land use changes on headwater stream temperatures in the Xingu Basin. Finally, validated numerical models were used to quantify the impact of land use at regional scales.

The field-based results showed two major impacts of deforestation: 1) runoff from croplands was approximately three times greater than that of native forest or cerrado watersheds; 2) water temperatures in headwater streams draining pasture and cropland were 2-4 oC higher than those draining forested watersheds. These runoff dynamics were well-represented by numerical models that incorporated local soil properties and infiltration, but not by hydrological models that rely on general soil parameters often based on temperate systems. There was also excellent agreement between measured and simulated estimates of evapotranspiration, soil water storage, and river runoff at the scale of both small and large river basins. Finally, the models of stream temperature indicated that warmer water temperatures were primarily driven by reductions in the width of bordering riparian forest vegetation and the presence of small impoundments in agricultural watersheds.

An integrated analysis of watershed dynamics in the Xingu clarified several important aspects of historical and potential future deforestation in the Xingu basin. Since 1970, deforestation has reduced forest cover in the 550,000 km2 basin by 16%, causing a small increase in discharge. However, that change was masked by a decrease in discharge, driven by decreased rainfall during this period. The modest scale of the change that has occurred so far is directly attributable to the large mosaic of public and private protected areas in the watershed. Without these protected areas, deforestation and related environmental impacts would likely have been much greater. Large-scale feedbacks from potential future deforestation in the Xingu watershed could reduce Xingu River discharge by an additional 6-36%, which in turn could reduce power production at the Belo Monte dam (currently under construction on the lower Xingu River) to 60% of its projected capacity.
